description: From Middle English particuler, from Anglo-Norman particuler, Middle French particuler, particulier, from Late Latin particularis (“partial; separate, individual”), from Latin particula (“(small) part”).  Equivalent to particle +‎ -ar. Compare particle.

adjectives.description: particular (comparative more particular, superlative most particular) (also non-comparable)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Pertaining only to a part of something; partial.

examples: I couldn't find the particular model you asked for, but I hope this one will do.
We knew it was named after John Smith, but nobody knows which particular John Smith.

entries.meaning: Specialised; characteristic of a specific person or thing.
examples: I don't appreciate your particular brand of cynicism.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Known only to an individual person or group; confidential.
Distinguished in some way; special (often in negative constructions).
examples: My five favorite places are, in no particular order, New York, Chicago, Paris, San Francisco and London.
I didn't have any particular interest in the book.
She was the particular belle of the party.

entries.meaning: (comparable) Of a person, concerned with, or attentive to, details; fastidious.
examples: Synonyms: minute, precise, fastidious; see also Thesaurus:fastidious
He is very particular about his food and if it isn't cooked to perfection he will send it back.
These women are more particular about their appearance.

entries.meaning: Concerned with, or attentive to, details; minute; circumstantial; precise.
examples: a full and particular account of an accident
a particular estate, or one precedent to an estate in remainder

entries.meaning: (logic) Forming a part of a genus; relatively limited in extension; affirmed or denied of a part of a subject.
examples: a particular proposition, opposed to "universal", e.g. (particular affirmative) "Some men are wise"; (particular negative) "Some men are not wise".

entries.meaning: A small individual part of something larger; a detail, a point. [from 15th c.]
(obsolete) A person's own individual case. [16th–19th c.]
examples: temporal blessings, whether such as concern the public […] or such as concern our particular

entries.meaning: (now philosophy, chiefly in plural) A particular case; an individual thing as opposed to a whole class. (Opposed to generals, universals.) [from 17th c.]
